header_summary:
The recent updates and discussions surrounding Bitcoin Core have highlighted significant developments and considerations within the Bitcoin ecosystem. The release of Bitcoin Core versions 29.2 and 30.0 brought a range of improvements and new features, emphasizing bug fixes, performance enhancements, updated translations, and a commitment to security and transparency. Notably, version 30.0 introduces limitations on legacy signature operations, increases in data carrier size for OP_RETURN outputs, and an innovative unified command-line tool, marking the end of maintenance for versions 27.x and older. These versions support Linux Kernel 3.17+, macOS 13+, and Windows 10+, with detailed upgrade instructions provided for different operating systems ([Bitcoin Core version 29.2](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-29.2/) and [version 30.0](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/)).

In parallel, discussions in the realm of network security and resource usage within proof systems have underscored the dynamic and complex nature of Bitcoin's technological landscape. The exploration of fingerprinting attacks within network security emphasized the importance of preparing for more effective strategies by understanding network topologies, while the practical considerations of resource usage in proof systems highlighted trade-offs between proof sizes and verification times, raising questions about the efficiency and feasibility of such systems in decentralized contexts. The exploration of these topics underscores the ongoing evolution of attack methodologies, defensive measures, and the technical trade-offs critical to blockchain technology's implementation and scalability ([Network Security](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/eclipsing-bitcoin-nodes-with-bgp-interception-attacks/1965/9), [Resource Usage in Proof Systems](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/proposal-op-stark-verify-native-stark-proof-verification-in-bitcoin-script/2056/2)).

Contributions from a wide range of individuals, including Amisha Chhajed, Eugene Siegel, fanquake, Greg Sanders, and many others, have been pivotal in advancing Bitcoin Core's development. These community-driven efforts reflect the collaborative nature of open-source projects and the continuous pursuit of innovation within the Bitcoin ecosystem.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.2 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.2 introduces bug fixes, performance improvements, and updated translations.
- The update supports Linux Kernel 3.17+, macOS 13+, Windows 10+, with advice against usage on less-tested systems.
- New features span P2P networking improvements, mempool adjustments, RPC and CI updates, and documentation enhancements.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.0 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 30.0 introduces new features, bug fixes, and performance improvements.
- Upgrading requires shutting down earlier versions; compatibility extends across Linux, macOS, and Windows.
- Changes include policy updates, network enhancements, a new command line tool, and wallet improvements.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 29.2 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- The latest Bitcoin Core release candidate, version 29.2rc2, is now ready for testing.
- It includes minor updates and improvements, with details available in the release notes.
- Feedback from this testing phase is crucial for finalizing the v29.2 official release.

recent_posts.title: Eclipsing Bitcoin Nodes with BGP Interception Attacks
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion addresses the importance of preparatory research for effective fingerprinting attacks on networks.
- It mentions TxProbe's uncertain effectiveness against such attacks and underscores the need for ongoing research.
- An educational initiative aims to improve network security through workshops and written materials, focusing on Lightning.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.2 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.2, featuring bug fixes and performance improvements, is now downloadable.
- This release enhances the peer-to-peer network, mempool component, RPC system, and CI processes.
- It supports Linux Kernel 3.17+, macOS 13+, Windows 10+, with contributions from numerous community developers.

recent_posts.title: Proposal: OP_STARK_VERIFY - Native STARK Proof Verification in Bitcoin Script

authors: On (in)ability to embed data into Schnorr waxwing/ AdamISZ

- AdamISZ explores embedding data in Schnorr signatures, questioning its security implications.

- AdamISZ invites critique of his findings, accessible via GitHub, fostering broader cryptographic discussion.

active_posts.title: Stats on compact block reconstructions
active_posts.summary:
- Compact block reconstructions in Bitcoin network analyzed, focusing on efficiency and need for additional transactions.
- Node configuration changes, such as `mempoolfullrbf=1`, seem to significantly impact block reconstruction efficiency.
- Investigation suggests potential benefits of policy adjustments and further research into factors affecting block reconstruction times.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin nodes and miners have adopted policies like full replace-by-fee and spam filtering.
- Compact block relay significantly reduces block propagation times, enhancing network efficiency.
- Template sharing and weak blocks aim to improve network robustness and transaction efficiency.

active_posts.title: Response to Pieter Wuille's StackExchange Answer Re: Nuking the Opreturn Filter
active_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's fee estimation is complex due to unpredictable miner actions and block times.
- Efforts to standardize mempools may increase centralization and censorship risks.
- A shift towards broader network heuristics for fee estimation is advocated.

today_in_history_posts.summary:

- He plans to publish his simulation code after finalizing his thesis or around Scaling Bitcoin.

today_in_history_posts.title: Single channel on mobile clients
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Multiple phone channels for third-party payments present various user challenges.
- Solutions include educating users on balance dimensions or recombining channel balances.
- Developers must select between single or multiple channels based on user needs.
